category: Substances that Extinguish Wind and Stop Tremors

action.primary: Extinguishes Wind, calms the Liver and stops spasms and tremors

indications: Liver Wind due to either Heat or Cold with headache, dizziness, childhood convulsions, epilepsy, tonic-clonic spasms, opisthotonos, tetany and Wind-stroke

action.primary: Extinguishes Wind, subdues Rising Liver Yang and alleviates pain

indications: Wind-Phlegm patterns with headaches, dizziness and migraines
Wind-stroke with hemiplegia, dizziness and numbness in the extremities
Can be used for both Excess and Deficiency conditions
Pain and numbness of the lower back and extremities due to Wind-Damp Bi

interactions: Concurrent administration of this herb with sedatives such as barbiturates, antihistamines, narcotic analgesics, benzodiazepines and many others, will lead to prolonged sedation.

useCases: Calms the Liver and extinguishes Wind.
Headaches, dizziness, blurred vision and tingling numbness of the extremities from Wind-Phlegm Attacking the Upper body and Internal Stirring of Wind.
Wind-stroke with hemiplegia and difficult speech.

Childhood convulsions from Wind-Phlegm.

Overwhelming attacks of Wind leading to migraines and dizziness so severe that the person feels as if they are about to fall over.
Difficulty in movement and deep-seated pain in the sinews and bones after Wind-stroke.
Wind-Damp Bi with difficulty bending the joints.
Wind-Damp leg Qi with pain in the sinews and bones and numbness of the skin.
Seizures.

Numbness and weakness of the extremities.
Bi pain with Blood Stasis.

notes: Depending on the other herbs, this herb can be used for problems due to Heat or Blood Deficiency.

This is the primary herb for settling Liver Wind and is often mixed with heavy sedating agents such as Concha Haliotidis #{ShiJueMing} Shi Jue Ming, Concha Ostreae #{MuLi} Mu Li, and Fossilia Ossis Mastodi #{LongGu} Long Gu, to enhance its action.
It is frequently used for headaches.
This herb governs head Wind, headache, dizziness, vertigo, epilepsy with strong convulsions, spasms in the four limbs, difficult speech and all Wind-stroke and Wind-Phlegm conditions.
This herb is traditionally believed to sharpen memory and promote strength.
It would be more used if it were less expensive. New cultivation techniques are helping to bring the cost down.
Some sources say that this herb disperses Wind-Damp Bi, stabilizes fright and moistens Liver Blood.
This herb is capable of promoting circulation in the cerebral and coronary arteries.
The principle treatment for Liver Wind is to nourish and move Blood.

Tian Ma and Ram. cum Uncis Uncariae #{GouTeng} Gou Teng are similar. Both calm the Liver and extinguish Wind to treat dizziness, vertigo and headache and are often used together. Gou Teng is sweet and Cold and treats Heat-induced Wind while Tian Ma is sweet warm and dry and treats Wind-Cold with Phlegm Dampness.
